headline.main: Sharpton Calls Limbaugh's Remarks About First Lady a 'Distraction'

docs.abstract: Comments Rush Limbaugh made on his radio show about Michelle Obama drew immediate attention because of his use of the word "uppity," which has racial implications.
docs.snippet: Comments Rush Limbaugh made on his radio show about Michelle Obama drew immediate attention because of his use of the word "uppity," which has racial implications.

docs.lead_paragraph: Just how racially heated will the 2012 presidential election get?

docs.lead_paragraph: Almost any vegetable can become a pasta accompaniment, and unusual noodle shapes enliven even the simplest pairings.
docs.snippet: Almost any vegetable can become a pasta accompaniment, and unusual noodle shapes enliven even the simplest pairings.

docs.lead_paragraph: I was intrigued (make that wildly excited) when I heard there was a fancy hotel in Switzerland where I'd be forced to eat meat, frites, cheese and chocolate and drink red wine and Champagne in order to lose weight. Was this a publicity ploy or a miracle? Whatever the case, the timing was exquisite. I'd had just about all the juice cleanses, freaky fasts and detox diets I could stomach, and was ready to bite off something I could actually chew. So, armed with an appetite and a copy of Gabrielle Hamilton's ''Blood, Bones & Butter,'' I set off for the sleepy city of Lausanne, which has stunning views of Lake Geneva and the Swiss Alps and one of Europe's grandest grande dame hotels - the Beau-Rivage Palace.
docs.snippet: I was intrigued (make that wildly excited) when I heard there was a fancy hotel in Switzerland where I'd be forced to eat meat, frites, cheese and chocolate and drink red wine and Champagne in order to lose weight. Was this a publicity ploy or a...

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are days when it seems -- both in and out of the food world -- that Everything Is Going Wrong. That makes it easy enough to complain, and I'm not alone in doing so routinely. Nothing tastes the way it used to. Even pricey restaurants have lost their glow. Quality is shot. People die from eating melons. The dominance of hyper-processed, industrialized food (and, more to the point, food-like products) is spreading globally, and we're all gaining weight faster than ever, while wrecking the planet. Nevertheless, it's nearly as easy to find signs of hope -- lots of them -- as well as people and organizations who've been prodding American food back on a natural, sustainable, beautiful track.
docs.abstract: Mark Bittman Op-Ed column highlights signs of hope in America's food culture, and offers his thanks in advance of Thanksgiving Day to all those who are working to help people eat better. Drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Instead of giving in to lobbyists, the Obama administration should be doing more to limit the way unhealthy foods are marketed to children.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges pushback from the Obama administration against food industry lobbyists attempting to undermine proposed voluntary standards aimed at curbing childhood obesity by limiting the way unhealthy foods are marketed to children.
docs.snippet: Instead of giving in to lobbyists, the Obama administration should be doing more to limit the way unhealthy foods are marketed to children.

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of people facing starvation dropped to nearly 250,000 from 750,000, the United Nations said Friday.

headline.seo: Somalia Famine Eases With Rainfall and Aid
headline.main: With Rainfall and Aid, the Number Facing Starvation in Somalia Drops by Half a Million
headline.print_headline: With Rainfall and Aid, the Number Facing Starvation in Somalia Drops by Half a Million

docs.abstract: United Nations reports that rainfall and increased aid deliveries have eased the drought-induced famine crisis in Somalia and significantly reduced mortality rates, but warns that Somalia's food security remains the worst in the world.
docs.snippet: The number of people facing starvation dropped to nearly 250,000 from 750,000, the United Nations said Friday.
